qas.question: What are some reasons for the lack of accurate Japanese capitals the Second Sino-Japanese War in the Sichuan Basin?
When was Guizhou the stronghold of Chiang Kai-Shek Koumintang's government?

context: In the 20th century, as <a1_0><b4_0><b10_0>Beijing, Shanghai, Nanjing, and Wuhan<b10_0/><b4_0/><a1_0/> had all been occupied by the Japanese during the Second Sino-Japanese War, <b6_0>the capital of the Republic of China had been temporary relocated to <a0_0><b5_0><b9_0>Chongqing<b9_0/><b6_0/><b5_0/><a0_0/>, then a major city in Sichuan. An enduring legacy of this move is that nearby inland provinces, such as <a2_0><b11_0>Shaanxi, Gansu, and Guizhou<b11_0/><a2_0/>, which previously never had modern Western-style universities, began to be developed in this regard. <a3_0><b12_0>The difficulty of accessing the region overland from the eastern part of China and the <b7_0>foggy climate<b12_0/><b7_0/><a3_0/> hindering the accuracy of Japanese bombing of the Sichuan Basin, made the region the stronghold of <b8_0>Chiang Kai-Shek's Kuomintang government<b8_0/> during <b13_0>1938-45<b13_0/>, and led to the Bombing of Chongqing.
